title: Public Policy Process
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: Through equipping students with knowledge of major concepts, models and theories of public policymaking process, this course aims to enhance the ability of students to understand and analyze public policy problems. The course consists of the following key components: foundation of public policymaking process and policy environment, competing models of policy-making, major policymaking actors and institutions, critical factors and stakeholders in major stages of policymaking. Case studies and real-world examples are used to illustrate how the theories are put into practice.
outcome: 1) Equip students of public policy and administration with substantive knowledge on public policy concepts, models and processes;2) Train students in the skill of public policy analysis through the use of specific techniques and case studies;3) Raise students’ awareness of the challenges and opportunities they may face in their future decision-making careers.
syllabus: This course discusses how public policy-makers go about defining problems, assembling evidence, constructing alternatives, selecting criteria, projecting outcomes, confronting trade-offs and, finally, making public policy decisions. The course specifically reflects on global economic, social, environmental, technological and legal factors affecting public policy process and decisions. Each of these contextual factors is dealt with theoretically, using internationally recognized public policy texts and, practically, through climate change-related case studies as follows:1) Economic factors and the deployment of the Green Climate Fund (GCF);2) Social factors and climate justice;3) Environmental factors and climate resilience to flooding in coastal cities;4) Technological factors and the uptake of renewable energy;5) Legal factors and the implementation of the Paris Agreement & its Rulebook.

title: Values and Ethics in Public Policy
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: This course aims to study the relationship between public polices and the values and ethics underlying them. It is the basic contention of this course that the making of public policies cannot be made divorced from moral and political values. These values provide justification for the legitimacy of policies. The course is divided into two parts. The first part introduces some major political theories and theoretical frameworks for students to understand the meaning and importance of values in different moral outlook. Values discussed cover rights and obligation, justice and fair procedure, freedom and democracy, community and citizenship, and the proper relation between personal and social responsibility. The second part focuses on case studies.
outcome: By the end of this course, students will be able to:1. Understand how different moral issues arise in the making of public policy.2. Develop moral framework to analyze and evaluate social policies and public affairs.3. Understand fundamental concepts and values in moral and political philosophy.4. Think critically and philosophically in the debates of public policies.5. Apply moral concepts to analyze public policies.
syllabus: It is the basic contention of this course that the making of public policies cannot be divorced from moral and political values. These values provide justification for the legitimacy of policies. The course is divided into two parts: The first part introduces major political theories and theoretical frameworks for students to understand the meaning and importance of values from different moral perspectives. Values discussed cover rights and obligations, justice and fair procedures, freedom and democracy, community and citizenship, and the proper relation between personal and social responsibilities. The second part focuses on case studies.Course Content1. Normative perspective on public policies2. Theoretical framework: utilitarianism, liberalism, and perfectionism3. Political theories: universal, comparative, and distributive justice4. Values and types of different political and governmental systems5. Values and public sector reforms6. Values and ethics for public organizations7. Values and ethics for public policy markers8. Values and ethics in public policy making9. Framework and principles for moral evaluation of public policies10. Ethics and code of conducts for professional practices11. Public leadership ethics

title: Public Policy Research
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: This course focuses on the application of methodological and statistical techniques in conducting policy research, with the objective of sensitizing students to adopt an evidence-based approach to assess public policies and social programs. Course contents include basic concepts in research designs, data collection techniques and statistical analyses. Discussions include both the qualitative and quantitative approaches to evaluate effectiveness, efficiency, and public accountability that define good public policies and social programs. Special attentions are given to the influences of the political environment and the competing interests among stakeholders in the research process. Real-world examples are used to illustrate practical skills in policy research.
outcome: (1) To understand the basic concepts of policy research;(2) To comprehend social, political, economic and organizational factors which influence the research process;(3) To acquire experiences in collecting and analyzing qualitative and quantitative information;(4) To develop a research proposal on an actual policy issue;(5) To relate research outcomes as inputs to policy formulation and implementation.
syllabus: The whole course consists of three parts. The first part introduces the basic elements: research question, theory, research design, and conceptualization. The second part discusses some qualitative methods, including case study, interviews, and content analysis. The final part focuses on quantitative methods: descriptive and inferential analysis, and survey research. For the quantitative part, Microsoft Excel will be used to conduct statistical analysis. The teacher will demonstrate the analysis steps in class where necessary. Students are expected to learn the basic skills of statistical analysis. This course also highlights the application and implication of methodological and statistical techniques in policy research. Therefore, real-life examples of public policies are discussed in class in order to advance students’ understanding and foster their policy analysis capacity.

title: Economic Analysis of Public Policy
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: The course objective is to provide students with useful economic tools to perform a benefit-cost analysis of public policy. It covers economic theories that help understanding how individuals, firms and government interact with one another. Relevant applications of economic theory to public policy in housing, health, labor, transportation, welfare, and environment are examined.
outcome: Students who have taken this course will  1) be able to apply economic tools for analyzing public policy, and  2) have a better understanding of the economic and financial context of public policy making
syllabus: Lectures will be given on topics including Economics and Economists, Prices, Competition, Market Failure, Firm, Competition Policies, Money, Trade, Nationalization VS Privatization, Rent-seeking, Competition among Governments, Top-down VS Bottom-up and Discretion VS Rules.
required_readings: Readings will be given by the instructor based on the topics covered.

title: Globalization, Social Problem and Policy
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: This course examines how policies of national government are shaped by the super-state institutions, such as the WTO, IMF and the World Bank, and how these relate to the current social problems in the World Cities, such as poverty, income disparity, marginalization of labour, etc. It will also explore the limits and possibilities of social policies of the national governments in alleviating such social problems.

title: Public Organization Management
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: Through discussing key questions in public organization theory and public management, the course examines how different aspects of public organizations, including their structure, environment and culture, can have an enormous impact on different stages of policymaking and policy outcomes. Emphasis of the course is on the understanding of the general theoretical frameworks of the field and the ability to apply them to the context of real-world problems and issues. Examples and cases from Hong Kong, China and major Asian and western countries are used for linking up the theory and practice.

title: NGOs & Government
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: This course examines the political, social and economic importance of NGOs in view of the theoretical discussions derived from a variety of empirical research in the Western countries and the practical experiences faced by NGOs in Hong Kong. The juxtaposition of theory and practice constitutes the major theme of the course. A number of NGOs are to be studied, ranging from interest groups, community groups, social movement organisations, to social service organisations and international NGOs. Emphasis is placed on the manners in which these organisations interact with government, political parties and other social groups in the local and international contexts.

title: Government and the Economy
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: The course identifies and analyzes the objectives and policies developed and pursued by the Government in managing the economy and how these policies are implemented to achieve the objectives. It will explore the Government's assumptions and approach to the economy and economic development, as well as monetary, fiscal, industrial, trade and investment policies. The Hong Kong Government serves as the primary case example, particularly the Financial Secretary's office, the HK Monetary Authority and Bureaus of Commerce and Economic Development and Financial Services and the Treasury.
outcome: 1. To develop concrete, practical knowledge and skills in economic policy analayis, development and application.  2. To provide guidance in devising and implementing policies that contribute to sustainable eocnomic growth and beneficial
syllabus: This course will identify and examine goals and policies developed and pursued by governments in managing the economy; how these policies are implemented to try to achieve these objectives; what tools are available and used by policymakers; various constraints affecting economic policy and policymaking; and the impact of policies on how we live and work.  It will explore Governments’ assumptions and approach to the economy and economic development, as well as monetary, fiscal, industrial, trade and investment policies. The Hong Kong and other Asian governments will serve as case examples of the development and implementation of policies and practices.

title: Public Policy and Governance
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy.
description: This course analyses the relationship between public policy and governance in a rapidly changing world. It gives a general picture of contextual challenges confronting contemporary governments in forming and implementing public policies and discusses the ways in which governments have attempted to cope with these contextual changes and challenges, and how governance theories in public administration and more broadly political science have been developed to study the evolving modes of policy-making since the early 1990s.
outcome: 1) To demonstrate an awareness of the fact that the environment in which governments make policies and organise the society has substantially changed; 2) To understand the changing mechanisms for governing in the recent decade and the impacts they bring about;  3) To reflect on both local and international cases and consider how they can contribute to a better understanding of public policy and administration in Hong Kong; and 4) To identity governing problems in the world and how the shared experience can help combat common governing problems faced by different governments.

title: Comparative Public Policy
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: The course objective is to explain policy outcomes of different political units, whether they are national or sub-national governments. The course also discusses some fundamental issues concerning the approach, scope and methods of doing comparative public policy. The course is divided into two parts. First, some foundational concepts, conceptual definitions and the underpinnings of doing comparative public policy will be given. Second, cases in major policy areas including Hong Kong, China and major countries in regions around the world will be examined by applying the concepts and theoretical frameworks introduced.
outcome: Understanding more about the conceptual and theoretical dimensions of comparative public policy. Becoming more open-minded and tolerant to different policies with various outcomes and they are different from the local contexts. Ability to integrate empirical findings with theoretical guidance. Working with student-fellows to have team spirit and group efforts. Presentation skills in the class and communication techniques are used. Coordination efforts between student-fellows to present findings and analyse data. Locate the policy debate within the Asian context, guided by a larger theoretical approach. Ability to think critically. Explore policy alternatives to the existing and pressing social issues and problems.
syllabus: This course examines the comparative study of the essence, characteristics, structure and process of public policies. The assumption is that through comparative study on countries (regions) based on substantive differences in institutions, different governance styles, developmental stages, and varied political processes that will entail differences for us to learn from each other. Put it simply, comparative public policy is to explain policy outcomes by comparing different political units, whether they are national or sub-national governments. The course offers foundational concepts and approaches in the field of comparative public policy, and begins with an introduction to the concepts of understanding comparative public policy. Questions and issues such as why comparative approach is needed to the study of public policy; What the significances and benefits of doing this are; And how it is conducted comparatively will be tackled, among many others. Then we will focus on a few substantive policies subsequently such as anti-corruption policy, higher educational policy, housing policy, poverty issue and aging policy. All these illustrate and demonstrate the importance, significance and insight drawn from the comparative study of public policy. In short, both conceptual ideas and empirical policies will be studied to enhance our understanding of public policies in a comparative manner. Moreover, practical implications and lessons will be drawn and learned. Last, but not the least, group presentations will be encouraged in the final weeks of the class. The number of groups will depend on the size of the class and the presentations should provide an excellent forum for us to engage in an active mode of discussion. Ideas can be tested; points will be made, and, above all, judgements shall be formed. This will further cultivate a sense of group learning within a productive and an encouraging academic environment.

title: Crisis Management and Public Governance
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: This course discusses theories and applications of crisis management and governance in the public service sector. It will also focus on how professionals in the public sector can reduce risks, get prepared, respond to and recover from crises for providing good governance.
outcome: By the conclusion of the course, students should have developed a deeper understand- ing and enhanced appreciation of crisis management concepts that could be brought to practice in real cases. In particular, the students are expected to have attained the following knowledge by the end of the course: A solid theoretical and practical base for studying and analyzing crisis phenome- na. Application of theoretical and practical skills to convey effective messages in crisis contexts. Analytical thinking to dissect crisis cases and to identify good and bad strategies. Recognition of potential ethical and legal problems in crisis management. Be able to engage in multi-thinking and multi-tasking in a crisis. Be able to know how to prevent/ minimize a crisis from happening. Be able to conduct a crisis prevention/ management and post-crisis management plan.
syllabus: This course is designed to (1) introduce students to the theory and application of crisis management; (2) guide students to understand the challenges imposed by the 3.0 era that has made crisis management all the more essential; (3) develop students’ analytical ability to dissect good and bad crisis cases and situations; and (4) train students to grasp the effective crisis management skills that work in real situations.

title: Climate Policy Analysis
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy;or MSSc Government and Politics (Greater China); or MSc in Sustainable Global Business.
description: The course covers a wide range of topics to systematically train students on climate and, more broadly, environmental policy analysis. It starts with an introduction to environmental externalities and the Environmental Kuznets Curve. It then focuses on analytical tools, including environmental valuation, carbon accounting, decomposition analysis, and cost-benefit analysis. The course also explores environmental justice and politics. Various climate/environmental policy instruments will be examined, including environmental impact assessments, voluntary agreements, emission taxes/fees, emission trading, and command and control regulations. The final module focuses on environmental governance, addressing climate change control, and culminates in a mock climate conference. Throughout, the course balances theoretical concepts with practical applications, providing students with a comprehensive understanding of climate policy analysis and environmental governance.
outcome: At the end of the course, students are expected to achieve the following learning outcomes: Understand the complexities of climate policy-making processes and their various stakeholders Apply analytical tools such as carbon accounting, decomposition analysis, and cost-benefit analysis to climate policy problems Critically evaluate the effectiveness of different climate policy instruments Analyze and compare climate policies at local, national, and international levels Develop skills in writing policy memos and recommendations for improving existing climate policies
syllabus: Lecture will be given on the topics as follows: Introduction: Externality, market failure, Environmental Kuznets Curve Valuing the environment: Value of a statistical life, discount rate, hedonic pricing Carbon accounting: ESG, Scope 1, 2, 3 emissions, double counting (decide on your own emissions) Decomposition analysis: Emission inventory, Activity, emission factor, practice decomposition Cost benefit analysis: Rational choice  Environmental justice and politics: Pollution heaven and migration, NIMBY, pollution/mitigation burden EIA & voluntary agreements: EIA, SEA; Information disclosure (design your label & let the other group to choose) Emission tax/fee: Environmental tax, fee, subsidy, deposit-refund, Payments for Ecosystem Services Emission trading: Market creation (property rights, cap and trade), Practice trading (record your transactions) Command and control: Mandatory and voluntary compliance, regulations, enforcement and compliance Environmental governance: Goal-centered, rule-based, central planning Control of climate change: Greenhouse gases, climate change, mitigation, energy transition, carbon neutrality; Kyoto Protocol and Paris Agreement Climate conference: Mock Conference of Parties for Climate Negotiation

title: Urban Planning and Development
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: In this course, different theories of planning and urban design are outlined, researched and adapted to current issues in Hong Kong and China. Urbanization, generic cities, the production of space, political planning, architectural culture and urban evolution will provide a contextual framework for the (re)vision of future environments in a critical and sustainable manner.

title: Global Finance and Governance
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: The purpose of this course is to analyze both short-term and long-term flows of capital across borders, the patterns they assume, the forces driving them. It also examines the benefits and costs/risks arising as a result, the instruments developed by private agents to maximize their effectiveness, government efforts to minimize the disruption caused, and the institiutional architecture which is emerging as a by-product of their rapid expansion.
outcome: Upon completion of this course, students will be able:1. To gain insight into the structure and functioning of the global financial system and its components;2. To understand the underlying rationale for, scope of, and limitations of international and national (or equivalent) financial regulatory mechanisms.

title: Government Relations, Diplomacy and Ethics
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy.
description: The course provides students with understanding of policy and government landscape and analysis of how organizations which operate across geographic boundaries can develop a consistent approach to Government Relations and Partnership Agreement strategies while ensuring the approach adopted is in accordance with the nuances of the different structures and processes on the ground. The course also will examine theories and case examples of political and regulatory advocacy projects to help students develop strategies and skills to organise and implement campaigns.

title: Public Policy in Hong Kong
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy.
description: With regard to Hong Kong as major case, the course will focus on and analyze the policy rationales and arguments put forward by the government, and the interaction between the administration and other stakeholders, including legislature, NGO, media and political parties. The course will also discuss the rising difficulties of the government in getting policy consensus from the general public and Legislative Council by illustrating intensive disputes of institutional reform, poverty problem, environment issues, and housing policies in Hong Kong.

title: Topical Studies in Public Policy I
requirements: For students in MSSc Public Policy
description: This course provides an in-depth analysis of important topics in public policy and government administration. Examples of these topics involve democratic governance, political sociology, social policy & welfare in Hong Kong & East Asia, political & economic transition in China, and program evaluation, etc. The topics of the course may vary according to the area of expertise of the instructor and the interest of the class.
